train_data.head()

source.c2846fed:
women = train_data.loc[train_data.Sex == 'female']["Survived"]
#print(women)
survived_rate_women = sum(women)/len(women)

print("% of women who survived:", survived_rate_women)
source.fafb890f:
men = train_data.loc[train_data.Sex == 'male']["Survived"]
# print(men)
survived_rate_men = sum(men)/len(men)

print("% of men who survived:", survived_rate_men)
source.1bf7985d:
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier

y = train_data["Survived"]

features = ["Pclass", "Sex", "SibSp", "Parch"]
X = pd.get_dummies(train_data[features])
X_test = pd.get_dummies(test_data[features])

model = RandomForestClassifier(n_estimators=100, max_depth=5, random_state=1)
model.fit(X, y)
predictions = model.predict(X_test)

output = pd.DataFrame({'PassengerId': test_data.PassengerId, 'Survived': predictions})
output.to_csv('my_submission.csv', index=False)
print("Your submission was successfully saved!")
source.1fde711d: **Statistics for numerical columns in the train dataset**
source.fe3d8628: **we can conclude that almost 75% of the women on board survived, whereas only 19% of the men survived. So, gender seems to be such a strong indicator of survival.**
source.6fb27298: **The majority of survived people was Female.**
source.d4bc35da: **It shows that in the train dataset, 549 people was died and 342 people was survived.**
